'Nicolas MÃ©tru' (ca. 1610 in Bar-sur-Aube1668 Paris) was a French organist, viol
player, and composer of pieces for viol and airs. From 1642 he was organist at
St. Nicolas-des-Champs, then some time later master of music for the Jesuits. He
taught Couperin and Lully and was an outstanding viol player. Marin Marais,
1656-1728: Volume 1 Clyde Henderson Thompson, Marin Marais - 1956 Metru was one
of Lully's teachers and an outstanding musician.

His first publication - which survives - was a collection of laudatory airs to
verse by Guillaume de BaÃ¯f, a minor poet but son of Jean-Antoine de BaÃ¯f, for
the victorious return of Louis XIII to Paris in 1628 after the end of the 14-
month siege of Protestant La Rochelle. Music, discipline, and arms in early
modern France - Page 270 Kate Van Orden - 2005 "95 Their unremarkable texts
express the knights' hunger for battle and laud the queen, who shines like a sun
over the French empire; they were penned by Guillaume de BaÃ¯f, a minor poet and
son of Jean-Antoine de BaÃ¯f." His third collection of airs also contains
laudatory texts, for the marriage of Louis XIV.

His duets for two viols (Paris, 1642) are the first printed example, and
therefore probably antedate the duets of Sainte-Colombe. Journal of the
Viola da Gamba Society of America: Volume 14 1977 "The tradition of such bicinia
goes far back into the 16th century. In France itself duets for two viols by
Nicholas Metru were published in Paris in 1642â thus very probably antedating
those by Sainte-Colombe." His fantasias for viols, as those of Henry and
MouliniÃ©, derive from the [[air de cour]] and the dance rather than older
styles. French baroque music from Beaujoyeulx to Rameau James R. Anthony -
1978 "and Nicholas Metru (died c. 1670), all wrote fantasias that, especially in
the case of Henry and MouliniÃ©, derived as much from the air de cour and the
dance as from the older imitative style of writing. His 1642 publication
reflects the change in development of the viol in the 1630-1650s with the upper
parts being written with the new smaller viols in mind. The viol: history of
an instrument Annette Otterstedt, Hans Reiners - 2002 Works such as that
published by Nicolas Metru (1642) still fitted the old viols in the lower parts,
whereas a smaller type of viol seems to have been likely for the upper parts,
